name: Propranolol (Inderal)
summary: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker used in the treatment of hypertension, angina, arrhythmias, migraine prophylaxis, and certain anxiety disorders.
description: Propranolol, marketed under the brand name Inderal and others, is a first-generation non-selective beta-blocker that blocks both β1- and β2-adrenergic receptors. This action reduces heart rate, myocardial contractility, and cardiac output, and also dampens the physiological effects of adrenaline, which can be useful in cardiovascular and anxiety-related conditions. Beyond cardiovascular indications, propranolol is also used for migraine prophylaxis, essential tremor, and management of physical symptoms of anxiety such as performance anxiety.

contraindications: Asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with bronchospasm
Second- or third-degree heart block without pacemaker
monitoring_required: Signs of bronchospasm in susceptible patients

sections.text: Propranolol works by competitively blocking β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors, reducing the effects of catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. This leads to decreased heart rate, myocardial contractility, and cardiac output, as well as reduced peripheral vasoconstriction and decreased tremor amplitude.

adult.Hypertension: 40 mg twice daily initially; maintenance 120–240 mg/day in divided doses
adult.Angina: 40–80 mg two or three times daily
adult.Arrhythmias: 10–30 mg three or four times daily
adult.Migraine prophylaxis: 80 mg/day in divided doses, titrated to 160–240 mg/day

sections.pediatric: Dose varies by indication and weight; typically 1–4 mg/kg/day divided into 2–3 doses
sections.geriatric: Initiate at lower doses; monitor for bradycardia and hypotension

items: Tablets: 10 mg, 20 mg, 40 mg, 60 mg, 80 mg
Extended-release capsules: 60 mg, 80 mg, 120 mg, 160 mg

sections.text: Onset: 1–2 hours (oral), immediate (IV); Duration: 6–12 hours (immediate-release), up to 24 hours (extended-release)

other: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension or angina—taper gradually
May mask signs of hypoglycemia in diabetic patients
Use caution in patients with bronchospastic disease

items.risk: Increased risk of bradycardia, heart block

sections.pregnancy: Category C; use only if benefits outweigh potential risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause bradycardia in infant
sections.geriatrics: Greater risk of bradycardia and hypotension; initiate with caution

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over 1–2 weeks to avoid withdrawal symptoms such as tachycardia, hypertension, or angina exacerbation

items: Particularly effective for controlling the physical symptoms of anxiety
Often used by performers or speakers to reduce stage fright
Avoid in patients with asthma unless benefits outweigh risks
